feat: Add new `grw` tactic for rewriting using inequalities.

Co-authored-by: @hrmacbeth, @digama0

```lean
example (x y z w : ‚Ñù) (h‚ÇÅ : x < z) (h‚ÇÇ : w ‚â§ y + 4) (h‚ÇÉ : Real.exp z < 5 * w) :
    Real.exp x < 5 * (y + 4) := by
  grw [h‚ÇÅ, ‚Üê h‚ÇÇ]
  exact h‚ÇÉ
```

nodes.body: The PR description here says it is still a work in progress. Do you want to update that?

> The PR description here says it is still a work in progress. Do you want to update that?

Yes. There are still features I want to add in the future but this PR is mergeable in my opinion.

Hi @sebzim4500 , today @hrmacbeth and I sat down and reviewed this code, resulting in some modifications and improvements in 329cbf51 that I have taken the liberty of pushing directly to the branch. Don't hesitate to speak up if you disagree or want clarification on the changes here. Summary of changes: 

* Use `IO.Ref` for persisting state through `withRwRulesSeq` instead of adding a `StateT` variant of the function
* Make `grw` transparently call `rw` when the hypothesis is an equality
  * thus `withRwRulesSeqState` becomes redundant and can be removed
* Inline/remove `grwHyp` into `grwAtLocal` and `grw` into `grwAtTarget`, rename `runGrw` to `grw`
* To avoid making too many assumptions about the inputs, `grw` core does not change any mvars, instead it returns a proof whose type is an implication in the specified direction.
* Interchange `withRwRulesSeq` and `withLocation`; this means `grw [a, b] at h1 h2` is equivalent to `grw [a] at h1 h2; grw [b] at h1 h2` instead of `grw [a, b] at h1; grw [a, b] at h2`, which matches how `rw` works and also makes the intermediate states between commas more sensible. (Previously using `grw [a, b] at *` would generate a large number of goals in the intermediate states because the same syntax is being tagged many times.)
* Use tactic state for persisting information rather than an `IO.Ref` or `StateT`. Besides being simpler to implement, this is also consistent with the `rw` tactic.
  * Downside: we do not track the fvar of the hypothesis being rewritten, so in theory a different hypothesis with the same name can jump in halfway through a rewrite chain (although examples that do this are extremely contrived)
  * Downside: Side goals come out in reverse order, i.e. we have `main goal, side goals for b, side goals for a` when doing `grw [a, b]`
  * Both of these are consistent with the `rw` tactic though, which we considered more important.
* Pass a template to `gcongr`, to improve the speed (and also catch some bugs).
* `dischargeSideGoal` is the same discharger used in `gcongr` itself, this is made the default in #8796
* `dischargeMainGoal` is replaced by `gcongrForward` with the specified `rule`
  * `gcongrForward` overlaps significantly with the `grw_weaken` attribute; the two have been merged and `grw_weaken` removed.
* The `progress` return value of `gcongr` is ignored - we don't really care if `gcongr` does nothing because it is being used on subgoals
* remove unnecessary partial and private from definitions
* add more docs
* Added some more tests
* reduced imports of test file

@hrmacbeth will push some more test files shortly but otherwise we support merging it. There are still some TODOs remaining, but they can be addressed in a follow-up PR:

* The `grw` lemmas are stored in a big bag and all applied to the goal. This should be replaced with some discrimination tree indexing or a lookup on the head symbol like in `gcongr`, this implementation does not scale and will likely become a problem if this tactic starts getting used widely (which we expect to happen, it's a very useful tactic).
* The attribute is not checked at application time, it is just a `LabelAttr`. We would like it to enforce some structure, both to make it easier for the user to apply the tag correctly, and also to improve the performance and precision of the tactic itself; currently it has some hacks to guess the structure of the lemma but these can be easily fooled.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8796~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!

pullRequest.title: feat: Add new `grw` tactic for rewriting using inequalities.

nodes.body: The PR description here says it is still a work in progress. Do you want to update that?

> The PR description here says it is still a work in progress. Do you want to update that?

Yes. There are still features I want to add in the future but this PR is mergeable in my opinion.

Hi @sebzim4500 , today @hrmacbeth and I sat down and reviewed this code, resulting in some modifications and improvements in 329cbf51 that I have taken the liberty of pushing directly to the branch. Don't hesitate to speak up if you disagree or want clarification on the changes here. Summary of changes: 

* Use `IO.Ref` for persisting state through `withRwRulesSeq` instead of adding a `StateT` variant of the function
* Make `grw` transparently call `rw` when the hypothesis is an equality
  * thus `withRwRulesSeqState` becomes redundant and can be removed
* Inline/remove `grwHyp` into `grwAtLocal` and `grw` into `grwAtTarget`, rename `runGrw` to `grw`
* To avoid making too many assumptions about the inputs, `grw` core does not change any mvars, instead it returns a proof whose type is an implication in the specified direction.
* Interchange `withRwRulesSeq` and `withLocation`; this means `grw [a, b] at h1 h2` is equivalent to `grw [a] at h1 h2; grw [b] at h1 h2` instead of `grw [a, b] at h1; grw [a, b] at h2`, which matches how `rw` works and also makes the intermediate states between commas more sensible. (Previously using `grw [a, b] at *` would generate a large number of goals in the intermediate states because the same syntax is being tagged many times.)
* Use tactic state for persisting information rather than an `IO.Ref` or `StateT`. Besides being simpler to implement, this is also consistent with the `rw` tactic.
  * Downside: we do not track the fvar of the hypothesis being rewritten, so in theory a different hypothesis with the same name can jump in halfway through a rewrite chain (although examples that do this are extremely contrived)
  * Downside: Side goals come out in reverse order, i.e. we have `main goal, side goals for b, side goals for a` when doing `grw [a, b]`
  * Both of these are consistent with the `rw` tactic though, which we considered more important.
* Pass a template to `gcongr`, to improve the speed (and also catch some bugs).
* `dischargeSideGoal` is the same discharger used in `gcongr` itself, this is made the default in #8796
* `dischargeMainGoal` is replaced by `gcongrForward` with the specified `rule`
  * `gcongrForward` overlaps significantly with the `grw_weaken` attribute; the two have been merged and `grw_weaken` removed.
* The `progress` return value of `gcongr` is ignored - we don't really care if `gcongr` does nothing because it is being used on subgoals
* remove unnecessary partial and private from definitions
* add more docs
* Added some more tests
* reduced imports of test file

@hrmacbeth will push some more test files shortly but otherwise we support merging it. There are still some TODOs remaining, but they can be addressed in a follow-up PR:

* The `grw` lemmas are stored in a big bag and all applied to the goal. This should be replaced with some discrimination tree indexing or a lookup on the head symbol like in `gcongr`, this implementation does not scale and will likely become a problem if this tactic starts getting used widely (which we expect to happen, it's a very useful tactic).
* The attribute is not checked at application time, it is just a `LabelAttr`. We would like it to enforce some structure, both to make it easier for the user to apply the tag correctly, and also to improve the performance and precision of the tactic itself; currently it has some hacks to guess the structure of the lemma but these can be easily fooled.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#8796~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ü§ñ). Happy coding!
